text: You know, I've told you before about provisional ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: In fact, I was thinking about writing about this this afternoon.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Provisional ballots came into existence in 2004.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: I believe it was when the.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: The legislation, it was called something like the Let People Vote Act.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: I'd have to go back and look up the name of the bill.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: But this was the legislation that George W. Bush pushed through Congress that was designed to solve the problem of Florida because Florida had all these different voting systems and whatnot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And it gave $5 billion to the states to buy voting machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: It was a big kind of pro-voting machine piece of legislation.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And what was interesting about it was it had this thing called a provisional ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And we'd never had provisional ballots before.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: It was called the Help America Vote Act, HAVA, was the piece of legislation.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And under HAVA, if you show up to vote but you're not registered to vote or you've been deregistered or removed from the voting rolls, you are still given a ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: It's called a provisional ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And you fill it out, and you think that you voted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: You feel like you voted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: But the only way that ballot gets counted is if you show up in person at the Secretary of State's office with your birth certificate and your ID and your passport or whatever the state requires to prove that you're an actual legal citizen and you live where you say you live.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And then the provisional vote can be counted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: So the vast majority of provisional ballots are just never counted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Well, Texas now has put 2.1 million people on a voter suspension list.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: They haven't done what Georgia, what Brad Raffsenperger and Brian Kemp have done in Georgia.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: They haven't removed people from the voting rolls.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Instead, what they've done is they've taken 2.1 million people, most of them in big cities and therefore presumably Democratic voters.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: They've taken 2.1 million people and put them on this list that they call suspended, which means that all 2.1 million of those people, when they show up to vote, will be given a ballot and they will think that they voted, but it will be a provisional ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And unless they show up at the Secretary of State's office in person within a couple of days of the election, their ballot will never be counted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: But they'll think they voted.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: So that way you don't get the blowback that you get in Georgia when people show up and they're told, I'm sorry, you're not getting on the voter rolls.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: See you later.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Go away.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: In this case, I mean, this is just such an elegant scam that Greg Abbott has put together in Texas.

text: This is a big deal.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And, you know, we need to be paying attention to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: I laid this all out in some detail in my book, The Hidden History of the War on Voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: And this has been, the provisional ballots have been a big part of the Republican war on voting ever since the Help America Vote Act was passed in the early 2000s.

text: Dr. Marty says there's one major red flag to look out for, cooked dog food, like kibble or canned food.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: When dog food is cooked at high temperatures, the amino acids often overheat, and that can create dangerous compounds called AGEs, or advanced glycation end products.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: AGEs can cause dangerous buildup in your dog's system and make them act slower or older than they are.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: High amounts may even be connected to cancer.

text: I'm Dr. Anthony Leiserwitz, and this is Climate Connections.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Climate change is a hot topic on college campuses.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: But when Audrey Rosa Vaitasi started school in North Carolina, she felt like few students could relate to her perspective on the issue.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: As an indigenous Pacific Islander from American Samoa, where sea level rise and intensifying storms are an urgent concern, she struggled to find people who understood her experiences.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: There's not a lot of Pacific Islanders present or other indigenous peoples.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So it was very difficult to try to see eye to eye with a lot of people.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: It's kind of like they don't really see where I'm coming from when I'm talking about climate change.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So, Savitasi greatly appreciates the Native Youth Climate Adaptation Leadership Congress, which is held each summer in West Virginia.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: She first went as a high school student and has now become a junior faculty member.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Participants take workshops and meet other Native youth who care about the climate.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Coming together with other Native tribes and Indigenous communities, you're able to really build on your roots as well as sort of adapt to understand different communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: It's just really beneficial to bounce ideas off of each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So she says it's a great opportunity to connect and collaborate.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Climate Connections is produced by the Yale Center for Environmental Communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: To learn more about climate change, visit climateconnections.org.
speaker: SPEAKER_07
